Title: My Life in Full: Work, Family, and Our Future
Review: Excellent memoir by an incredible and inspiring CEO. I found Nooyi’s personal perspective from her life fascinating and inspiring as she brought those experiences to create meaningful and impactful change. Here influence was not limited to PepsiCo but beyond to the partners, workers, and even nations with which the company is involved. I think anyone can learn a lot from her story and experiences, and I think there are many opportunities to carry her work in the next generation.

Title: Against Technoableism: Rethinking Who Needs Improvement
Review: Excellent book. When we view those with a disability of some form as needing fixed or that a technological innovation will cure them, their individuality and desires are ignored. After finishing up _Under a White Sky_, I have been very aware of how human interventions always have unintended or unexpected consequences, and technoableism is no different.

Title: Under a White Sky: The Nature of the Future
Review: I’ve read both Kolbert’s _Field Notes From a Catastrophe_ and _The Sixth Extension_, both of which highlight the effects of the Anthropocene. While _Under a White Sky_ dives more in to how as we try to solve problems, we inevitably cause more problems, which cyclically leads to more damage and more problems to solve. Kolbert explores many examples of what has been done, what is being fixe, and where we are theorizing other solutions and trying to anticipate the damage the solution may cause.

Title: The Buddha in the Attic
Review: Beautiful and harrowing novel told through the lives and experiences of Japanese immigrants to the Western United Stated from turn of the 20th century up to the mass detainment during World War 2. I learned so much through this book that was difficult to put down. What I found most impressive is that the protagonist is not a person but a people, with each sentence providing a perspective.

Title: How Infrastructure Works: Inside the Systems That Shape Our World
Review: Incredible deep dive in to the hidden systems that intertwine our everyday lives. Deb Chachra takes you all over the globe to look at what was, what is, and what could be when it comes to these systems. I was astounded by many structures she presents and equally left concerned with how societally we ignore the essentialness of these systems’ regular maintenance needs.

Title: Bad With Money
Review:
I have considered reading this book for years. In part because I think I am bad with money, but know I know more than I give myself credit. However, Dunn’s book title instilled a honesty I never see from financial books.
Bad With Money is the perfect book for those transitioning from teenager to adult to get a level-head grip on the weird world of every day finances. It’s also a really good book for anyone just trying to figure all this shit out, because none of us fully understand it all.
What stood out to me for this book was the thesis early on as Dunn discusses the scripts we follow when it comes to money and that these scripts get instilled in us early in life as the grown-ups in our lives grapple with understanding money, too. As I read Dunn’s own account of her life and how it informed her money scripts, I realized my own money script revolved around fear and shame. Recognizing that, I hope to dig more into the roots of that.
That’s not all though, Dunn covers everything from making money, saving, investing, to the blight of the student loan system and wedding industries taking advantage of uninformed youth. Dunn also covers things you may not consider like a will and how we can be part of changing how our society relates to and perceives finances and money.
I absolutely loved Dunn’s insight and humor as she interweaved her personal story with financial insights she’s gleaned over the years. I highly recommend this book even if you feel very confident in your financial understanding as Dunn’s own perspective reminded me how differently everyone’s experience is as we figure life.

Title: God, Human, Animal, Machine: Technology, Metaphor, and the Search for Meaning
Review: I was drawn to this book from the perspective as someone seeing similarities with the Posthuman/Transhuman push from the techno-authoritarians and that of Christian fundamentalism. Indeed, O’Gieblyn takes on both and more in a fascinating exploration of the metaphors that transcend humanity, religions, and systems that are religion in all but name.

Title: Women & Power: A Manifesto
Review: I have been wanting to read Mary Beard for some years ever since I learned about her book SPQR. But, I’ve put off picking up her works until now, and I’m glad this was my introduction to her work. Beard brings to the forefront how the suppression of women during ancient Greece and Rome is still alive and well in Western Civilization today.

Title: The Empress of Salt and Fortune
Review: Absolutely beautiful story.

Title: Extremely Hardcore: Inside Elon Musk’s Twitter
Review: Zoë Schiffer’s provides a deeply researched and developed account of the the moment Elon Musk tweeted he’d buy Twitter, up through the end of the first year after he took over. I found this to be a page turner that provided further depth on stories I had heard or read through her reporting on Platformer. All-in-all, it’s amazing X Corp. hasn’t announced bankruptcy as of this writing.

Title: Angelika Frankenstein Makes Her Match
Review:
I really should have realized this was necrophilia by the title. However, I thought it was in the spirit of something like *Pride and Prejudice and Zombies*. And while the main character fantasized her formerly-dead piecemeal creation vividly, there was just enough story thread to keep me going until I realized I was actively avoiding reading altogether.

In order to appease my completionist mindset, I skimmed and skipped through the remainder of the book to mark it as read. The characters lacked anything that made them the least bit interesting, and by the end I found now substantial development to the characters or the story.

Title: Sea of Tranquility
Review: quite the page turner. I had a very hard time putting this one down. Emily St. John Mandel uses pandemic as a backdrop once again to explore humanity in an even more fascinating way than *Station Eleven*. Loved it and this is high on the reread list already.

Title: The Poppy War
Review:
I don’t quite know what to say about this book. After this one, I want to read everything Kuang has written, and might make that a goal for the year. I will certainly have to finish the trilogy at the least. 

When I first read the premise, this seemed like it ought to be labeled YA. A young, neglected kid rises above the expectations of their abusive guardians to join an elite school and find their hidden power. But this is far beyond that stereotypical synopsis and makes itself known that it is no YA story. Here, the dangers are real, the war is grizzly, and the awkward love triangles don’t exist.

I found this to be a page turner in every way I would want. I was left so often wanting to keep reading, but also with a desire to pause and digest what I had just finished reading. Now I have to consider whether to pause and pick up a different book or the sequel.

Title: Of Time and Turtles
Review: Another beautiful account from Sy Montgomery, exploring the depths of a particular group of creatures. I did not realize the very intentional threat turtles face through various acts of humanity to poach and profit. These are creatures I have long been fascinated by, and this book introduced me to people that have devoted their lives to the well-being of these slow neighbors. As Sy often does, I’m left with a new-found respect for the topical animal.

Title: Inclusive Design Communities
Review: A Book Apart Books always bring quality in words, ideas, and the physical product itself. The paper quality, and layout choices are of equal quality as the author, topic, and writing. Sameera’s book is no different. While it is called Inclusive Design Communities it could also be called Being an Empathetic Human. So much of her ideas and thoughts in this book transcend the tech industry and can be applied to any place humans gather.

Title: Strange Weather in Tokyo
Review: Beautiful story about a woman and the relationship she builds with her childhood school teacher later in life. So much of the book ends up talking about the food at various place around Tokyo that I would have to stop reading because I got hungry.

Title: Bookshops & Bonedust
Review: I love these books and I need Travis Baldree to keep going back to this world of low stakes, high fantasy. Even when it does get more intense, it still manages to be laid back. Great read for the end of year holidays.

Title: Design That Scales: Creating a Sustainable Design System Practice
Review: Excellent book by the one and only, Dan Mall. He captures so many thing about creating not just good design systems, but good design teams.

Title: The Sunlit Man: A Cosmere Novel
Review: Wonderful end to the Year of Sanderson.

Title: The Way of Kings: Book One of the Stormlight Archive
The Frugal Wizard’s Handbook for Surviving Medieval England
The Ones We're Meant to Find
The Well of Ascension: Book Two of Mistborn
Heir to the Empire: Star Wars Legends: The 20th Anniversary Edition
The Ocean at the End of the Lane: A Novel

The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet

The Murder of Roger Ackroyd
Review: Agatha. Your writing is amazing. I can’t believe this book is pushing 100.

Title: The Innovator's Dilemma: When New Technologies Cause Great Firms to Fail
How Will You Measure Your Life?
Authors: James Allworth, Clayton M. Christensen, Karen Dillon

Title: Bel Canto
Review: This was an absolutely beautiful book. My first time reading Ann Patchett and I can say this won’t be my last.

Title: This Is How You Lose the Time War
The Return of Captain John Emmett
The Boat
Review: This was a random find at the local used bookstore. I picked it up on a whim and so glad I did. Nam Le’s stories pulled me in. Each story is a snapshot of a human experience in this bleak and beautiful world.

Title: The Clothing of Books
Review: Jhumpa Lahiri’s observations on book cover designs and her own personal relationship with book covers was so candid. As a trained graphic designer, I’m often left questioning the visual choices made by book cover designers. I often prefer hardcovers with the intent on removing the jacket, leaving a naked, minimal, and often more interesting presentation of the book. The perspective and the experience Lahiri has with book covers brings a

Title: Love Wins: A Book about Heaven, Hell, and the Fate of Every Person Who Ever Lived
World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
Snow, Glass, Apples
Review: Fantastic, fresh take on an old classic

Title: When Captain Flint Was Still a Good Man
Antifragile: Things that Gain from Disorder
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
Reclaiming Conversation: The Power of Talk in a Digital Age
Essentialism: The Disciplined Pursuit of Less
Why Not Me?
Review: I really enjoyed listening to Mindy Kaling talk through many different aspects of her life and some alternative universe what ifs. The part that struck me the most was the final chapter where she addresses a question she is asked often “how she is so confident.” Her thoughts on the matter were very encouraging for me as I’ve been learning over the years how to be confident, but wanting to stay humble as my confidence grows.

Title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Authors: Brian Selznick (Illustrator), J. K. Rowling, Mary GrandPré (Illustrator)

Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
A Briefer History of Time
Authors: Stephen Hawking, Erik Davies, Leonard Mlodinow

Title: Nietzsche in 90 Minutes
Review: I’ve never really known much about Nietzsche. His name was thrown around a good bit in my college German courses. This was a nice little biography and gave me some decent sources to delve into more, including Nietzsche’s own work, of course.

Title: I'd Rather Be Reading: The Delights and Dilemmas of the Reading Life
Empathy for the Devil: Finding Ourselves in the Villains of the Bible
The Soul of an Octopus: A Surprising Exploration into the Wonder of Consciousness
1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created
All the Pieces Matter: The Inside Story of the Wire®
Triggers: Creating Behavior That Lasts--Becoming the Person You Want to Be
Review: I heard about this book from episode 66 of the Cortex podcast (https://www.relay.fm/cortex/66). I was listening along thinking this was another typical business book that they recommend, but my ears perked when they got talking about these journalling type questions the author asks of himself and his clients. That alone had me intrigued, and I liked a good bit of what the author had to say on the topic, the examples were very real life

Title: Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow
The Old Man and The Sea
Saga

Title: I'm Still Here: Black Dignity in a World Made for Whiteness
Reading People: How Seeing the World Through the Lens of Personality Changes Everything
Nimona
Review:
Wonderful and fun story

I fell in love with these characters. For such a short and simple story to have such depth was lovely and welcoming.

Title: What Every Christian Needs to Know about the Jewishness of Jesus: A New Way of Seeing the Most Influential Rabbi in History
Stories of Your Life and Others
Review: Each story was a page turner for me. Ted Chiang immerses you into each story quickly that they feel like looking into another world that is strangely familiar.

Title: Wild Ones: A Sometimes Dismaying, Weirdly Reassuring Story about Looking at People Looking at Animals in America
Review: When I started this book, I took it as being in the vein of [a:Elizabeth Kolbert|45840|Elizabeth Kolbert|https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1380812913p2/45840.jpg]’s [b:The Sixth Extinction|17910054|The Sixth Extinction  An Unnatural History|Elizabeth Kolbert|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1372677697s/17910054.jpg|25095506] and [b:Field Notes from a Catastrophe|80513|Field Notes from a Catastrophe  Man, Nature, and Climate Change|

Title: The Revenge of Analog: Real Things and Why They Matter
1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus
Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World
The Girl with All the Gifts
Notorious RBG: The Life and Times of Ruth Bader Ginsburg
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
The Road Back to You: An Enneagram Journey to Self-Discovery
The Disaster Artist: My Life Inside the Room, the Greatest Bad Movie Ever Made
Review: I have not seen The Room yet, but after reading Greg’s account of its production I hope to rectify that soon. The Room is considered The Citizen Kane of bad movies, another movie I have yet to see, and I've seen plenty of YouTube clips to understand why. Sestero’s account presents the heart and mind of the man behind the film, well as best as he can at least. Moreover, this is a story of an unlikely and difficult friendship.

Title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
David and Goliath: Underdogs, Misfits, and the Art of Battling Giants
The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses, and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution
Review: Fascinating history of computer technology from Ada Lovelace up the modern era.

Title: What the Dog Saw: And Other Adventures
The Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make a Big Difference
Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis
Review: J.D. Vance is a year younger than me and we grew up in the same area of Ohio. We both have Appalachian family as well. Many things sounded familiar, not from personal experience, but from observing and living amongst many of the same folks. I found this book to be a wonder reminder of who many of my neighbors are, and what there story looks like.

Title: Finding God in the Waves: How I Lost My Faith and Found It Again Through Science
The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History
A Year of Biblical Womanhood: How a Liberated Woman Found Herself Sitting on Her Roof, Covering Her Head, and Calling Her Husband Master
The Devil Wears Nada: Satan Exposed
